speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: SCENE II. The same. The Capitol.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Enter two Officers, to lay cushions

speaker: First Officer
text_entry: Come, come, they are almost here. How many stand

speaker: First Officer
text_entry: for consulships?

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: Three, they say: but 'tis thought of every one

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: Coriolanus will carry it.

speaker: First Officer
text_entry: That's a brave fellow; but he's vengeance proud, and

speaker: First Officer
text_entry: loves not the common people.

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: Faith, there had been many great men that have

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: flattered the people, who ne'er loved them; and there

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: be many that they have loved, they know not

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: wherefore: so that, if they love they know not why,

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: they hate upon no better a ground: therefore, for

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: Coriolanus neither to care whether they love or hate

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: him manifests the true knowledge he has in their

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: disposition; and out of his noble carelessness lets

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: them plainly see't.

speaker: First Officer
text_entry: If he did not care whether he had their love or no,

speaker: First Officer
text_entry: he waved indifferently 'twixt doing them neither

speaker: First Officer
text_entry: good nor harm: but he seeks their hate with greater

speaker: First Officer
text_entry: devotion than can render it him; and leaves

speaker: First Officer
text_entry: nothing undone that may fully discover him their

speaker: First Officer
text_entry: opposite. Now, to seem to affect the malice and

speaker: First Officer
text_entry: displeasure of the people is as bad as that which he

speaker: First Officer
text_entry: dislikes, to flatter them for their love.

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: He hath deserved worthily of his country: and his

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: ascent is not by such easy degrees as those who,

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: having been supple and courteous to the people,

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: bonneted, without any further deed to have them at

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: an into their estimation and report: but he hath so

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: planted his honours in their eyes, and his actions

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: in their hearts, that for their tongues to be

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: silent, and not confess so much, were a kind of

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: ingrateful injury; to report otherwise, were a

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: malice, that, giving itself the lie, would pluck

speaker: Second Officer
text_entry: reproof and rebuke from every ear that heard it.

speaker: First Officer
text_entry: No more of him; he is a worthy man: make way, they

speaker: First Officer
text_entry: are coming.

speaker: First Officer
text_entry: A sennet. Enter, with actors before them, COMINIUS  the consul, MENENIUS, CORIOLANUS, Senators,  SICINIUS and BRUTUS. The Senators take their  places; the Tribunes take their Places by themselves. CORIOLANUS stands

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Having determined of the Volsces and

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: To send for Titus Lartius, it remains,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: As the main point of this our after-meeting,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: To gratify his noble service that

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Hath thus stood for his country: therefore,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: please you,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Most reverend and grave elders, to desire

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: The present consul, and last general

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: In our well-found successes, to report

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: A little of that worthy work perform'd

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: By Caius Marcius Coriolanus, whom

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: We met here both to thank and to remember

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: With honours like himself.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Speak, good Cominius:

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Leave nothing out for length, and make us think

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Rather our state's defective for requital

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Than we to stretch it out.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: To the Tribunes

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Masters o' the people,

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: We do request your kindest ears, and after,

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Your loving motion toward the common body,

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: To yield what passes here.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: We are convented

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Upon a pleasing treaty, and have hearts

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Inclinable to honour and advance

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: The theme of our assembly.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which the rather

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: We shall be blest to do, if he remember

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: A kinder value of the people than

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He hath hereto prized them at.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: That's off, that's off;

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: I would you rather had been silent. Please you

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: To hear Cominius speak?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Most willingly;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But yet my caution was more pertinent

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Than the rebuke you give it.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: He loves your people

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: But tie him not to be their bedfellow.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Worthy Cominius, speak.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: CORIOLANUS offers to go away

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Nay, keep your place.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Sit, Coriolanus; never shame to hear

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: What you have nobly done.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Your horror's pardon:

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I had rather have my wounds to heal again

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Than hear say how I got them.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Sir, I hope

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: My words disbench'd you not.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: No, sir: yet oft,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: When blows have made me stay, I fled from words.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: You soothed not, therefore hurt not: but

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: your people,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I love them as they weigh.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Pray now, sit down.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I had rather have one scratch my head i' the sun

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: When the alarum were struck than idly sit

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To hear my nothings monster'd.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Masters of the people,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Your multiplying spawn how can he flatter--

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: That's thousand to one good one--when you now see

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: He had rather venture all his limbs for honour

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Than one on's ears to hear it? Proceed, Cominius.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: I shall lack voice: the deeds of Coriolanus

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Should not be utter'd feebly. It is held

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: That valour is the chiefest virtue, and

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Most dignifies the haver: if it be,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: The man I speak of cannot in the world

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Be singly counterpoised. At sixteen years,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: When Tarquin made a head for Rome, he fought

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Beyond the mark of others: our then dictator,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Whom with all praise I point at, saw him fight,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: When with his Amazonian chin he drove

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: The bristled lips before him: be bestrid

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: An o'er-press'd Roman and i' the consul's view

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Slew three opposers: Tarquin's self he met,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: And struck him on his knee: in that day's feats,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: When he might act the woman in the scene,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: He proved best man i' the field, and for his meed

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Was brow-bound with the oak. His pupil age

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Man-enter'd thus, he waxed like a sea,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: And in the brunt of seventeen battles since

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: He lurch'd all swords of the garland. For this last,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Before and in Corioli, let me say,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: I cannot speak him home: he stopp'd the fliers;

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: And by his rare example made the coward

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Turn terror into sport: as weeds before

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: A vessel under sail, so men obey'd

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: And fell below his stem: his sword, death's stamp,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Where it did mark, it took; from face to foot

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: He was a thing of blood, whose every motion

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Was timed with dying cries: alone he enter'd

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: The mortal gate of the city, which he painted

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: With shunless destiny; aidless came off,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: And with a sudden reinforcement struck

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Corioli like a planet: now all's his:

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: When, by and by, the din of war gan pierce

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: His ready sense; then straight his doubled spirit

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Re-quicken'd what in flesh was fatigate,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: And to the battle came he; where he did

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Run reeking o'er the lives of men, as if

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: 'Twere a perpetual spoil: and till we call'd

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Both field and city ours, he never stood

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: To ease his breast with panting.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Worthy man!

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: He cannot but with measure fit the honours

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Which we devise him.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Our spoils he kick'd at,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: And look'd upon things precious as they were

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: The common muck of the world: he covets less

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Than misery itself would give; rewards

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: His deeds with doing them, and is content

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: To spend the time to end it.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: He's right noble:

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Let him be call'd for.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Call Coriolanus.

speaker: Officer
text_entry: He doth appear.

speaker: Officer
text_entry: Re-enter CORIOLANUS

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: The senate, Coriolanus, are well pleased

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: To make thee consul.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I do owe them still

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: My life and services.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: It then remains

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: That you do speak to the people.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I do beseech you,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Let me o'erleap that custom, for I cannot

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Put on the gown, stand naked and entreat them,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: For my wounds' sake, to give their suffrage: please you

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That I may pass this doing.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Sir, the people

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Must have their voices; neither will they bate

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: One jot of ceremony.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Put them not to't:

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Pray you, go fit you to the custom and

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Take to you, as your predecessors have,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Your honour with your form.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: It is apart

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That I shall blush in acting, and might well

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Be taken from the people.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Mark you that?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To brag unto them, thus I did, and thus;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Show them the unaching scars which I should hide,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: As if I had received them for the hire

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Of their breath only!

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Do not stand upon't.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: We recommend to you, tribunes of the people,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Our purpose to them: and to our noble consul

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Wish we all joy and honour.

speaker: Senators
text_entry: To Coriolanus come all joy and honour!

speaker: Senators
text_entry: Flourish of cornets. Exeunt all but SICINIUS and BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You see how he intends to use the people.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: May they perceive's intent! He will require them,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: As if he did contemn what he requested

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Should be in them to give.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Come, we'll inform them

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Of our proceedings here: on the marketplace,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I know, they do attend us.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt
